===Etymology 2===
{{ja-kanjitab|つる|yomi=k}}
{{wikipedia|lang=ja|ツル}}
Given a crane's long neck and how the bird hunts, possibly related to {{m|ja|蔓|tr=tsuru||vine}}; {{m|ja|弦|tr=tsuru||bowstring; musical instrument string}}; {{ja-l|釣る}}, {{m|ja|吊る|tr=tsuru||to hang down; to string up; to fish}}. Given how cranes flock together, possibly related also to {{m|ja|連る|tr=tsuru}}, older root form of modern verb {{m|ja|連れる|tr=tsureru||to accompany}}. That said, {{ja-l|連る}} also appears to ultimately derive from {{m|ja|蔓|tr=tsuru||vine}}.

Likely Altaic cognates include {{cog|trk-pro|*durunja||crane}} (whence {{cog|tr|turna}}), {{cog|ko|-}} {{ko-inline|두루미|durumi|crane}}, {{cog|mn|тогоруу||crane}}|tr=togoruu). Compare also {{cog|hu|daru||crane}}.

The reading ''tsuru'' is first seen used to mean {{m|en|crane|a crane|pos=the bird}} from the late [[w:Heian period|Heian period]]. Prior to that time, the only reading used for the bird was ''tazu''. However, the kanji {{lang|ja|鶴}} was used in the [[w:Man'yōshū|''Man'yōshū'']] as a phonetic [[ateji]] for the verb ending ''-tsuru'', suggesting that ''tsuru'' may have already existed as an everyday term meaning {{m|en|crane|a crane}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref>
